dataset.title: Quail Ridge/Stebbins Cold Canyon/Jepson Prairie Reserve Herpetofaunal Reference Collection Data

creator.organizationName: University of California Natural Reserve System

abstract.para: This dataset presents information associated with a multipurpose, specimen-based herpetofaunal reference collection for Quail Ridge, Stebbins Cold Canyon, and Jepson Prairie Reserves. The reference collection consists of two physical elements: non-lethal tissues, and sacrificed whole-body specimens plus tissues. The utility of this collection is multifaceted. It represents a long-term repository of tissues suitable for molecular analysis, a permanent assemblage of whole-body vouchers for teaching and research, and a taxon-specific micro-distribution database to encourage ecological study of herpetofauna at the reserves. The dataset consists of precise locality information (GPS coordinates, microhabitat descriptions), morphometric measurements (size, mass), and other relevant information for each tissued or sacrificed animal.

additionalInfo.para: This data file is in excel format, with two sheets in the file (one sheet for tissue specimens, and one sheet for whole-body voucher specimens).

intellectualRights.para: Obtain permission from data set owner(s)

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Inner North Coast Ranges and Sacramento Valley, CA.

taxonomicCoverage.generalTaxonomicCoverage: Stebbins, R. C., and S. M. McGinnis. 2012. Field guide to amphibians and reptiles of California, revised ed. University of California Press.

section.title: Opportunistic and Targeted Herpetofaunal Surveys
section.para: Reptiles and amphibians included in this dataset were collected by hand, seine, dip-net, lizard noose, submersible turtle trap, and by flip-and-replacement of natural and artificial cover objects. Sampling effort was focused on documenting taxa from as many localities on the reserves as possible. As such, for common species, localities with large numbers of conspecific study subjects were only lightly sampled, in favor of broader sampling of conspecifics at multiple locations. Pond- or stream-breeding amphibians were the exceptions: for these taxa large sample sizes were collected at every discrete breeding site we surveyed. Animals were obtained by searching any habitat deemed suitable for a species known or suspected to occur on the reserves. Surveys for terrestrial taxa generally involved walking through suitable habitat types, and searching for surface-active animals or animals present under cover objects. Surveys for aquatic taxa involved trapping (for turtles), or seining/dip-netting ponds.

description.para: All species of herpetofauna known or suspected to occur at each reserve were targeted for inclusion in this dataset, with few exceptions. Surveys and sampling were conducted across all habitat types at each reserve. Taxa were targeted only when seasonal conditions were most conducive to maximal sampling efficiency. For example, plethodontid salamanders were targeted immediately after rainstorms, and whiptail lizards were targeted in the summer. Sampling at the reserves was fairly regular (roughly one survey per week, on average) at Stebbins Cold Canyon and Quail Ridge between late March and late July, 2012. Sampling was much less frequent at Jepson Prairie, since it hosts a comparatively depauperate herpetofaunal assemblage relative to the other two reserves. In the future, sampling at these three reserves will be more infrequent and opportunistic, with surveys initiated only to fill gaps in the existing dataset presented here.

samplingDescription.para: The goal of this project’s sampling was to rapidly obtain tissue from 20 individuals, and sacrifice up to three voucher specimens, per species per reserve. For pond- or stream-breeding amphibians, these sampling numbers were increased to a per-breeding-site basis, rather than a per-reserve basis. The sampling protocols implemented to achieve this goal were not standardized or replicable. Estimating relative abundance or population sizes of herp taxa, or comparing the data to future surveys as part of a monitoring scheme, are not appropriate applications for this dataset. Instead, the dataset could be consulted as pilot information by researchers interested in answering those questions, to allow them to choose productive study sites.
